The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

History:
The Foster and Kinship Care Education program was established in the California Community College's Chancellor's Office in 1984 following the passage of Senate Bill 2003, known as the Foster Children and Parent Training Act. This act designated the Chancellorâs Office as the agency to administer the program and provide funding to the community colleges for the provision of education and training to potential and existing foster parents.
	 
Foster and Kinship Care Education (FKCE) Program Mission:
The mission of the Foster and Kinship Care Education Program is to provide quality education and support opportunities to caregivers of children and youth in out-of-home care so that these providers may meet the educational, emotional, behavioral and developmental needs of children and youth in the foster care system.
	 
Funding:
The Chancellor's Office receives funding for the FKCE program from two primary sources. State funding consists of community college Proposition 98 funds. These State funds are used as a match to pass through federal Title IV (e) funds, by way of an interagency agreement with the California Department of Social Services.
	 
College Responsibilities:
EVC provides specialized and advanced training designed to teach knowledge and skills for kinship and relative caregivers:  EVC recruits facilitators to teach the workshops, schedules child care, invites foster parents to the workshops and reserves classrooms with county social services.
	 
TERM
This MOU is effective February 21, 2011 between SSA and EVC and shall remain in effect until June 30, 2011, unless terminated earlier or otherwise amended. Provisions of the term include an option of two additional one-year terms. Delegation of authority expires on June 30, 2013.  There is no exchange of funds related to this MOU.

At the recommendation of the colleges, the District entered into a contract with Higher One, Inc. in January 2011 to disburse financial aid via direct deposit to students effective the summer 2011 term.  Students who elect not to have the disbursement deposited into his or her personal bank account are issued a debit card linked to an account established by Higher One, Inc.; thereby, allowing the student to access his or her financial aid award.
	 
Section 8.1 of the contract imposes an "Inactive Replacement Card Fee" of $10 per replacement for additional card orders from a student when he or she does not authenticate or activate his or her card and requests a replacement card, presumably due to loss.  This fee is charged to the District.
	 
It is recommended that this $10 fee is charged to the student who is requesting the replacement card.
	 
Per Exhibit C of the contract, there is a one-time 60-day amnesty period after the initial issuance of the debit cards as the District and students transition to the new disbursement process.  The District nor the student, if the Board of Trustees approves this recommendation, will be charged the fee during this 60-day period.
	 
A copy of the executed contract is attached for reference.

items.item_details:
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  This is a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond with a 55% voter approval threshold and carries the requirement of a citizens' bond oversight committee.
 
On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District’s desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District was seeking the services of a Program/Construction Manager to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 Program. The Program Manager shall ensure proper definition and implementation of the work and maximize value to the District and colleges through effective program and construction execution. 
 
Proposals were due to the District on March 11, 2011.  The selection committee consisted of the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services, the College Presidents, and the Interim Controller, with the assistance of a content expert in the construction field.  The District received six proposals and agreed to interview three firms:  Gilbane Building Company, Kitchell, and Parsons.  The unanimous decision was to select Gilbane Building Company based on their experience with community college bond programs, the proposed cost structure, the location of their staff and their supporting office in San Jose, and the quality of their presentation and proposal.
 
This initial contract is for the first year and includes program mobilization, scheduling, strategic program planning for implementation and design, and general program support at the campuses and the District.  The first year contract will be time and materials only at a not to exceed amount of $2,200,000.  The College Presidents and Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services will approve all staffing in advance and direct the work of the program teams. The Program Manager will be working with the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services to ensure overall program accountability and compliance.  Detailed timelines and task lists are attached as well as answers to trustee questions.
 
The contract also contains a unique clause which holds Gilbane accountable for quality assurance: Quality Assurance Plan Accountability.  The District expects the Program Manager staff to use their collective expertise and long experience in the construction industry to bring to the attention of District staff problems relating to quality in the design and construction of the projects along with recommended solutions.  An amount not to exceed 3% of the Program Manager’s monthly billing will be withheld by the District and released quarterly based on the Program Manager’s successful implementation of their Quality Assurance Program.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the agreement with Gilbane Building Company as the Measure G-2010 Program and Construction Management Firm.

Background and Analysis: 
	 
At the June 9, 2009 Board of Trustees meeting, the Board received a report on the CDC Centers.  This report summarized key findings unearthed during an assessment of the CDC Centers at EVC and SJCC.  The EVC CDC was closed, and the site leased to an outside agency.  Several recommendations were made at that time in order to foster the continuance of the CDC program at SJCC.  During the 2009-10 academic year, another review was conducted for SJCC CDC, including feedback from students, employees and the community and a review of fiscal trend data. 
	 
Although strategies were identified to increase the cost effectiveness of the Center, most were not implemented.  As a result, current research findings include:
	 
·We have insufficient funds to cover all the costs associated with the CDC; the district has had to use general fund dollars to augment the budget every year.  
	 
·The age and condition of the Center create a less than desirable environment for children and will require significant maintenance. 
	 
·The CDC is not ADA compliant. 
Subsequent to the Board meeting on May 10th, additional information has been gathered related to the Child Development Center:
	 
Although there are several documents associated with our bond initiative that include the Child Development Center, it is absent in SJCC’s Master Facilities Plan and in the final list of projects for both Measure G 2004 and Measure G 2010.  We have been unable to determine why the CDC was not included in the final project lists. On May 2nd, we learned from our Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services that bond funds could be used to complete needed repairs to the building.  Therefore, we have not included the cost for repairs in the estimated shortages below:
	 
General fund backfill that has been and will be needed to cover CDC budget:
	 
2009-2010:         $159,195
2010-2011*:        $210,710
2011-2012*:        $282,676
*estimated
	 
Although some alternative strategies have been identified to reduce the current budget gap, coverage of the anticipated shortfall is still uncertain; therefore, due to the budget shortfall we are facing, the President recommends closing the facility.
	 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 051011-2, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.
	 
Identified are (11) positions to eliminate, (11) employees who are to be laid off, and (1) employee who may be bumped due to exercising of seniority rights.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
	 
Keys to Success is a three-week learning disabilities testing, educational accommodation, and innovative classroom program designed specifically to empower CalWORKs clients.  Funded by the County of Santa Clara since 2001, Evergreen Valley College has been the contracting institution to provide much needed educational training referrals and assessments for CalWORKs students.  Since its inception, Keys to Success provided over 2,000 at risk and vulnerable CalWORKs students with educational and training opportunities to assist them and their families in becoming self-sufficient. 
	 
·        Due to state budget reductions, the County of Santa Clara is unable to fund the program at its current level.  For fiscal year 2010-11, the contract for Keys to Success is $515,000.  However, the County is reducing the contract to $204,000 for fiscal year 2011-12.  
	 
·        The contract amount for fiscal year 2011-12 is dependent upon state funding to the County of Santa Clara. 
	 
·        The Keys to Success Program is being redesigned to continue much of its work, and it will remain a contract for Evergreen Valley College.  
	 
	 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 051011-3, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.
	 
	 
Identified are (2) positions to eliminate, (2) employees who are to be laid off, and (2) employees who may be bumped due to exercising of seniority rights.

items.item_details:
On January 25, 2011, in accordance with BP 2745, the Board of Trustees initiated their annual evaluation process by establishing a Board Self Evaluation Committee and appointing Trustees Cruz, Lease and Okamura to serve on that committee.  The committee was asked to work with the Chancellor to develop a process and criteria for the evaluation of the Board.  On March 8 the Committee reported on their work to the full board and presented information on the proposed focus of the board self evaluation; namely, (1) Board Operations and Effectiveness, and (2) Shared Accreditation Findings. A survey methodology was recommended for the proposed work; and, in addition, the committee proposed strengthening the process by including a representative sample of district-wide internal constituents as well as members of the external community.  It is important to note, that BP 2745 does not require others outside the board to participate in the process, thus making this last recommendation unprecedented in nature.  The full board expressed consensus with the proposed methodology and established May 10 as a deadline for a report on the findings.
 
This item complies with the requirements established for the Board Self Evaluation Committee and includes a review of the methodology, analysis of the findings and conclusions formatted along recurrent themes.  In addition, the report presents a construct to compare and contrast the evaluation responses provided by board members and those provided by internal constituents.  The Committee will facilitate a public discussion based on the findings and will offer proposed "next steps" for consideration by the full board at a subsequent meeting.
 
It is expected that the Board Self Evaluation process will result in useful data to establish guidelines for the development of a work plan, including board development activities where necessary.  It is the express intent of the Board of the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District to use the outcomes of the self evaluation process not only to guide their future work but as clear evidence of intent to address accreditation concerns regarding role, function and the exercise of board leadership.
